description: From Middle English bekerven, bikeorven, from Old English beċeorfan (“to becarve, cut off, separate, cut or pare away, deprive a person of something by cutting, amputate, behead”), equivalent to be- +‎ carve. Cognate with Old Frisian bikerva (“to amputate”).

verbs.description: becarve (third-person singular simple present becarves, present participle becarving, simple past becarved or (archaic) becorve, past participle becarved or (archaic) becorven)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete, land) To cut up; cut open; open up.
(transitive) To cut; carve or cut up; cut in pieces; carve.
